Award.AwardTitle: Student Research Network in the Physics of Living Systems: Georgia Tech Node
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project, the PIs at Georgia Tech (GT) will join the existing Physics of Living Systems Student Research Network. Growth of the GT program will: 1) bring research topics in underrepresented areas to the PoLS SRN, 2) integrate PoLS at GT into the broader bio-related community at GT, in turn creating a hub in the Southeast of the US for PoLS, 3) create sustained interaction with faculty at world-leading institutions while lubricating opportunities for national and international collaborations, 4) create new PoLS experimental, modeling and theoretical tools, 5) create new PoLS curriculum, 6) train students and postdocs who can advance PoLS at GT and become the next generation of PoLS researchers. The co-PIs on this proposal include four scientists from the Biophysics Group in the School of Physics (SoP), one from Mechanical Engineering, and a senior member of the SoP. They are joined by approximately 20 faculty within and outside the SoP who have research interests that fall within the scope of PoLS. These represent areas within the College of Sciences and the College of Engineering at Georgia Tech. In the last five years, the SoP at Georgia Tech has begun to develop a program in biophysics with the goal to become a world leader in this area, and also help develop technologies that can advance both basic science and human health. The core Biophysics Group in the SoP (consisting of four primary faculty and four adjunct faculty) seeks to understand how physics can inform questions of structure, function and dynamics in biological systems, and to study fundamental physics questions posed by biological systems. As a goal for future growth and leadership, the group intends to build on the successes and strengths of the nonlinear science and soft matter communities at GT. A second goal is to integrate their program with the already world-class engineering programs (specifically bioengineering) at GT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Beginning in 2007, the School of Physics (SoP) at the Georgia Institute of Technology has developed a program in biological physics (now called Physics of Living Systems) with the goal to become a world leader in this area, and also help develop technologies that can advance both basic science and human health. During the years of membership in the PoLS SRN, we focused on building our PoLS program. Membership in the SRN allowed us to expand the PoLS faculty during the years since the GT node was funded; these include hires of Gumbart, Fenton, Sponberg and Yunker — a Soft Matter hire who works on pattern formation and mechanics in multicellular ensembles. The PoLS SRN funding has allowed continued development of individual faculty research programs, collaborations and space allocation. We have developed a strength in organismal PoLS, particularly with the addition of Sponberg and Fenton. GT Physics has also grown in Soft Matter, an area which synergizes with PoLS, through hires of Yunker as well as two theoreticians with some PoLS related interests. Several of our Nonlinear Dynamics faculty work with PoLS faculty, e.g. Grigoriev and Cvitanovi? with Fenton on cardiac dynamics, Wiesenfeld with Goldman on locomotion dynamics, Sponberg & Grigoriev on fluid dynamics during flight. The funding also created of a PoLS seminar series. Notable activities include (but are not limited to):

Weekly “Lunch and Learns”: Our weekly “Lunch and Learns”, L2, have generated a sense of community for students, postdocs and PI/SP and have led to new collaborations within the node and externally. Each Thursday noon-1:30PM, students (and visitors) gather in a room with AV equipment and eat lunch, have some discussion and listen to a talk. A different student organizes the events for a given semester. A list of talks and abstracts can be found on the wiki page. The L2 are highly interactive with attendees peppering the speakers with questions. Typical attendance is ~40 faculty, postdoc & students.

            Jump-starting research collaborations:  Goldman and Hu have worked with Zoo Atlanta to develop infrastructure to study snake locomotion on sand. Gumbart has a productive collaboration with Kim and Steve Harvey (emeritus in biology). Weitz and Kim collaborated and published on a quantitative biology project [5]. Hu works closely with a Soft Matter faculty member, Prof. Alberto Fernandez-Nieves on rheology of living active matter. Kim also collaborated with Fernandez-Nieves to study the effect of geometry on colony growth. Wiesenfeld and Weitz published theoretical work on bacteria lysis. Goldman and Wiesenfeld have worked on several projects, including publishing a paper on hopping robots, and recently a study of collective dynamics of smart-active-particles. Weitz and Curtis recently initiated a combined theoretical-experimental program to study the  synergistic elimination of bacterial microcolonies by immune cells and viruses.

Course Development, Educational Efforts, Outreach and Mentoring: GT faculty in the PoLS SRN node are expanding GT course offerings in SoP through development of new courses. Goldman developed a hands-on PoLS survey course. Hu has developed several labs based focused organismal courses integrating the Center for Disease Control (CDC) and Atlanta Botanical Gardens.  Hu’s  trade science book for Princeton University Press on the physics of animal movement is under review.  Sponberg and Fenton developed a Neurophysics lab based course. Weitz has created a new Quantitative Bioscience PhD program that leverages interaction with PoLS faculty (who function as “home school” participants); the incoming class included 9 students of which four are advised by PoLS faculty. The second class includes 7 students of which we expect half to be advised by PoLS faculty. Weitz has developed a new course "Foundations of Quantitative Biosciences" offered as part of the QBioS PhD and open to Physics PhD students as well – the objective is to combine nonlinear dynamics and physical principles to understand the structure and function of living systems. Weitz's book on Quantitative Viral Ecology awarded 2016 Postgraduate Textbook Prize in Biology from Royal Society of Biology. Gumbart, Kim and Curtis have developed a cellular/molecular biophysics course. Gumbart is leading an effort to create a PoLS minor in SoP. In terms of outreach, most PoLS faculty give public lectures and have some engagement with local high schools. Curtis and Gumbart have developed (building from UMD’s course) an Introductory Physics of Living Systems/Physics for Life Scientists (IPLS), running since Fall 2016, whose goal is develop an intro physics curriculum enjoyed by students from life sciences background. Faculty and students are also heavily involved with outreach and mentoring, with a notable example being GT’s Women in Physics (WIP) program. Fenton has also begun outreach to underrepresented groups. Curtis is the PI of a REU site program focused on diversity in physics; 10 out of 20 of these students (2016, 2017) were placed with PoLS faculty.
